questions.text: Choose the word that best fits the blank: The constant noise _____ the neighbors.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'vexed'. From the PDF (Word 1 - Vex): Meaning = to annoy or irritate persistently. Exact original example: 'The constant noise vexed the neighbors.' Etymology (Latin vexāre = to shake/agitate) explains why it feels like mental 'shaking'. Options 0,2,3,4 are antonyms (soothe/please/delights/pacify) – common trap in SSC/Bank exams to test antonym confusion.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate synonym for 'Imprecation':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Curse'. PDF (Word 2 - Imprecation): Detailed meaning = a spoken curse/invocation of evil. Synonyms listed: Curse, Malediction, Hex. Etymology (Latin imprecārī = to pray evil upon) helps remember it as 'praying harm'. Other options are exact antonyms from PDF (Blessing, Benediction, Praise).

questions.text: Choose the word that is the ANTONYM of 'Prodigal':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Thrifty'. PDF (Word 3 - Prodigal): Meaning = wastefully spending money. Antonyms explicitly given: Thrifty, Frugal, Economical. Biblical allusion ('prodigal son') noted in PDF. Other options are exact synonyms. High-frequency SSC pattern.

questions.text: Fill in the blank with the most suitable word: Many city-dwellers dream of an _____ retirement in the hills.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'arcadian'. PDF (Word 4 - Arcadian): Meaning = ideal, peaceful countryside. Exact example from PDF: 'Many city-dwellers dream of an arcadian retirement in the hills.' Etymology (Greek Arkadia = pastoral paradise) makes it memorable. Other options are direct antonyms (urban, metropolitan, hectic, cosmopolitan).

questions.text: Choose the word closest in meaning to 'Importunate':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Persistent'. PDF (Word 5 - Importunate): Meaning = persistently demanding in an annoying way. Synonyms: Persistent, Insistent, Demanding. Etymology (Latin importūnus = no harbour/refuse) shows why it feels 'hard to refuse'. Other options are exact antonyms from PDF.

questions.text: Select the correct synonym for 'Taciturn':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Reserved'. PDF (Word 6 - Taciturn): Meaning = quiet and not talkative. Synonyms: Silent, Reserved, Reticent. Mnemonic from PDF: TACIT-URN (keeps words inside). Other options are exact antonyms (talkative/garrulous/chatty/voluble).

questions.text: Choose the word that is the ANTONYM of 'Untoward':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Favourable'. PDF (Word 7 - Untoward): Meaning = unexpected and unfavourable. Antonyms: Favourable, Convenient, Advantageous. Etymology (Old English 'not toward') clarifies direction. Other options are synonyms.

questions.text: Fill in the blank: The project ran _____ the aegis of UNESCO.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'under'. PDF (Word 8 - Aegis): Fixed collocation = 'under the aegis of' (meaning protection/sponsorship). Exact original example: 'The project ran under the aegis of UNESCO.' Etymology (Greek aigís = shield of Zeus) explains protection imagery. This phrase appears in 90% of editorial-based exams.

questions.text: Choose the closest meaning of 'Obduracy':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Stubbornness'. PDF (Word 9 - Obduracy): Meaning = stubborn refusal to change. Synonyms: Stubbornness, Inflexibility, Obstinacy. Etymology (Latin obdūrāre = to harden) + mnemonic (OB-DUR-ACY = hard like rock). Other options are exact antonyms.

questions.text: Select the best word for the blank: She gave a _____ summary of the topic.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'pithy'. PDF (Word 10 - Pithy): Meaning = short but meaningful. Exact example: 'She gave a pithy summary of the topic.' Etymology (Middle English 'pith' = core/essence). Other options are exact antonyms (wordy/verbose/diffuse/rambling).

questions.text: One-word substitute: A person who makes maps.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Cartographer'. PDF One-Word Substitutes section: 'Cartographer – A person who makes maps.' Expanded example: 'The cartographer’s accurate maps helped in disaster management.' Direct match from PDF.

questions.text: Choose the correct one-word substitute: Scientific study of celestial bodies.
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Astronomy'. PDF: 'Astronomy – Scientific study of celestial bodies.' Expanded: 'ISRO’s achievements have boosted India’s astronomy research.' Distinguishes from Astrology (belief-based) as highlighted in PDF.

questions.text: Choose the correct meaning of the phrasal verb 'Break through':
options: Force a way through / achieve success
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Force a way through / achieve success'. PDF Phrasal Verbs (BREAK): 'Break through – Force a way through / achieve a major success.' Examples: 'Scientists finally broke through in cancer research.' Common in RC & cloze tests.

questions.text: The meeting _____ at 5 pm. (Choose correct phrasal verb)
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'broke up'. PDF: 'Break up – Disperse / end.' Exact example: 'The meeting broke up at 5 pm.' Tests particle change in meaning – frequent Bank/SSC pattern.

questions.text: Choose the correct meaning of 'A thorn in one’s side':
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Constant source of trouble'. PDF Idioms (Danger/Risk): 'A thorn in one’s side – Someone or something that constantly causes trouble.' Exact example: 'The rival company has been a thorn in our side for years.'

questions.text: The idiom 'Playing with fire' means:
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Taking dangerous risks'. PDF: 'Playing with fire – Taking dangerous risks.' Example: 'Investing all savings in one crypto coin is playing with fire.' High-frequency danger idiom in editorials.

questions.text: 'A snake in the grass' refers to:
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Someone secretly plotting against you'. PDF: 'A snake in the grass – Someone who is secretly plotting against you.' Example: 'The trusted assistant turned out to be a snake in the grass.'

questions.text: Choose the meaning of 'Between a rock and a hard place':
options: Being in a difficult situation where both options are bad
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'Being in a difficult situation where both options are bad'. PDF: 'Between a rock and a hard place – No good options; difficult dilemma.' Example: 'The CEO was between a rock and a hard place – sack employees or face losses.'

questions.text: The idiom 'Skating on thin ice' means:
options: To be in a dangerous or risky situation
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'To be in a dangerous or risky situation'. PDF: 'Skating on thin ice – To be in a dangerous or risky situation.' Example: 'Commenting on politics at the office party is skating on thin ice.'

questions.text: In the sentence 'His _____ prevented reconciliation', the blank is best filled by:
questions.solution: Correct answer: 'obduracy'. PDF (Word 9): Exact example 'His obduracy prevented reconciliation.' Meaning = stubborn refusal to change. Tests full recall of example + meaning together – ultimate competitive exam skill.
